question: Which of the following synthetic androgens is classified as a 2,3-isoxazol-17α-ethynyltestosterone derivative?
Which synthetic androgen has a 1:2 androgenic to anabolic activity ratio and shows limited conversion to dihydrotestosterone (DHT)?
Which of the following agents is administered both orally and sublingually?
A synthetic androgen with oral activity, longer half-life, and reduced hepatic metabolism is most likely to be:
Which of the following is known for being less active in the reproductive system due to limited conversion to dihydrotestosterone?
Which androgen is least likely to undergo rapid hepatic metabolism and can therefore be administered orally?
Which of the following synthetic androgens may appear unchanged in the urine?
Which of the following androgens is structurally classified under testosterone analogs?
Which of the following best describes the pharmacokinetic advantage of synthetic androgens such as methyltestosterone?
Which of the following is both synthetic and orally active, and exhibits enhanced stability due to a modified ring structure?
Which of the following drugs should be avoided in patients with renal failure?
Potassium‐sparing diuretics are contraindicated when used concurrently with which of the following agents?
Which of the following drugs exhibits anti‐progesterone activity?
Which diuretic is most commonly associated with menstrual irregularities, decreased libido, hirsutism, hoarseness, and impotence?
Which drug pair’s effects can be inhibited by probenecid?
Which of the following diuretics is known to inhibit the reabsorption of potassium, hydrogen ions, and magnesium in the distal convoluted tubule?
Thiazide diuretics are considered the mainstay in the management of which condition by a paradoxical mechanism?
Which of the following agents would not be effective in the management of hypertension?
Potassium sparing diuretics exert their primary diuretic action at which nephron segment?
options: Late distal convoluted tubule and collecting duct

question: Potassium sparing diuretics are routinely combined with loop diuretics in the management of:
Eplerenone combined with Ethacrynic acid is utilized for the treatment of:
In patients with hepatic dysfunction, loop diuretics are contraindicated because sodium depletion may precipitate which complication?
Significant potassium loss due to loop diuretic therapy, if not adequately replaced, may lead to:
Loop diuretic use should be avoided with the following agents except:
Which of the following is another name for thyrotropin?
Which of the following inhibits iodide organification within the thyroid gland?
Tetraiodothyronine is primarily excreted as which of the following?
Which of the following best describes a disorder where antibodies function as agonists at thyrotropin receptors?
The antithyroid activity of compounds like propylthiouracil is attributed to the presence of which functional group?
Which of the following drugs blocks the peripheral conversion of tetraiodothyronine to triiodothyronine?
Which of the following drugs is known to appear in breast milk?
Which of the following is an established therapeutic use of propylthiouracil?
Which of the following is a documented adverse effect of methimazole?
What is the half-life of radioactive iodine?
Which of the following drugs should never be co-administered with quinidine due to the risk of exacerbating quinidine-associated torsades de pointes via hypokalemia?
Which osmotic diuretic is approximately 80% metabolized in the liver?
Among the following osmotic diuretics, which agent has the shortest elimination half-life?
Osmotic diuretics are known to inhibit the reabsorption of several ions in the renal tubule. Which of the following ions is not listed among those whose reabsorption is inhibited?
Thiazide diuretics may provoke metabolic disturbances. Which of the following adverse effects is most characteristically associated with their use?
What is the typical onset of action of potassium iodide in thyroid therapy?
Which of the following is a recognized adverse effect of iodide therapy?
Pertechnetate is rarely used in clinical practice due to its association with which of the following adverse effects?
Which of the following agents is indicated for emergencies such as myxedema coma due to its rapid onset?
Which of the following is a physiological action of androgens?
Which of the following statements best describes the pharmacokinetics of testosterone?
options: It is highly effective when given orally due to bypass of first-pass metabolism
It binds strongly to thyroxine-binding globulin in plasma
It is rapidly absorbed but extensively metabolized by the liver when taken orally
It is eliminated unchanged in the urine

Which diuretic is most commonly associated with menstrual irregularities, decreased libido, hirsutism, hoarseness, and impotence?
Which drug pair’s effects can be inhibited by probenecid?
Which of the following diuretics is known to inhibit the reabsorption of potassium, hydrogen ions, and magnesium in the distal convoluted tubule?
Thiazide diuretics are considered the mainstay in the management of which condition by a paradoxical mechanism?
Which of the following agents would not be effective in the management of hypertension?
Potassium sparing diuretics exert their primary diuretic action at which nephron segment?
options: Late distal convoluted tubule and collecting duct

question: Potassium sparing diuretics are routinely combined with loop diuretics in the management of:
Eplerenone combined with Ethacrynic acid is utilized for the treatment of:
In patients with hepatic dysfunction, loop diuretics are contraindicated because sodium depletion may precipitate which complication?
Significant potassium loss due to loop diuretic therapy, if not adequately replaced, may lead to:
Loop diuretic use should be avoided with the following agents except:
Which of the following is another name for thyrotropin?
Which of the following inhibits iodide organification within the thyroid gland?
Tetraiodothyronine is primarily excreted as which of the following?
Which of the following best describes a disorder where antibodies function as agonists at thyrotropin receptors?
The antithyroid activity of compounds like propylthiouracil is attributed to the presence of which functional group?
Which of the following drugs blocks the peripheral conversion of tetraiodothyronine to triiodothyronine?
Which of the following drugs is known to appear in breast milk?
Which of the following is an established therapeutic use of propylthiouracil?
Which of the following is a documented adverse effect of methimazole?
What is the half-life of radioactive iodine?
Which of the following drugs should never be co-administered with quinidine due to the risk of exacerbating quinidine-associated torsades de pointes via hypokalemia?
Which osmotic diuretic is approximately 80% metabolized in the liver?
Among the following osmotic diuretics, which agent has the shortest elimination half-life?
Osmotic diuretics are known to inhibit the reabsorption of several ions in the renal tubule. Which of the following ions is not listed among those whose reabsorption is inhibited?
Thiazide diuretics may provoke metabolic disturbances. Which of the following adverse effects is most characteristically associated with their use?
What is the typical onset of action of potassium iodide in thyroid therapy?
Which of the following is a recognized adverse effect of iodide therapy?
Pertechnetate is rarely used in clinical practice due to its association with which of the following adverse effects?
Which of the following agents is indicated for emergencies such as myxedema coma due to its rapid onset?
Which of the following is a physiological action of androgens?
Which of the following statements best describes the pharmacokinetics of testosterone?
options: It is highly effective when given orally due to bypass of first-pass metabolism
It binds strongly to thyroxine-binding globulin in plasma
It is rapidly absorbed but extensively metabolized by the liver when taken orally
It is eliminated unchanged in the urine
